newsitem.title: UK: North Sea crudes firm, Med buyers see weaker sours.
newsitem.headline: North Sea crudes firm, Med buyers see weaker sours.

text.p: North Sea crudes rose slightly on Wednesday in a quiet market which some traders said was propped up by evidence of Brent crude sailing to the U.S.
The June Brent contract traded 10 cents firmer at $18.16 a barrel by 1233 GMT in a follow-through to a rally late on Wednesday.

Physical activity was thin but traders said the market drew support from the sale on Wednesday of two Brents due to load May 2-4 and May 6-8 to a trader seen sending a VLCC to the U.S. Gulf. The cargoes fetched June Brent -40 and -45 cents respectively, traders said.
There were also signs that other North Sea grades were strengthening. A Statfjord May 18-20 sold by an equity holder on Wednesday changed hands at Dated Brent +14 or +15 cents, traders said.
Two Brent cargoes. loading May 9-11 loading, were due to turn wet on Thursday.
On the paper market, intermonth spreads were slightly firmer with May/June talked at -23/-20 cents and Jun/Jul -13/-11 cents.
Brent CFDs were mixed, April 28-02 trading twice at June Brent -43 cents, one cent over Wednesday's levels, and May 5-9 talked at June Brent -43/-40 cents, a fall of about three cents.
North Sea sentiment was propped up by thinner early May supply with only a couple of offshore loaders still unsold in the first half of May, traders said.
"I don't think there's an awful lot (on offer). I think it is getting sold out for the first decade," a trader said.

Mediterranean sour benchmark Urals held firm, supported by robust margins for high sulphur fuel oil, but signs of lengthening supply and an array of alternatives kept refinery buyers relaxed. "Sellers are still asking high numbers for prompt barrels but I'm sure Urals will start heading back towards (Dated Brent) -$1.20 very soon," said one.

Urals was pegged at around Dated Brent -$1.05 a barrel, basis cif Augusta, on Wednesday. Traders asked about Dated Brent -$1.00 for large cargoes loading in the first 10 days of May, but buyers said the offers were at least 10 cents too high.

"With Urals close to (Dated) -$1.00 it's not only Kirkuk which looks better but Iranian Heavy and Syrian Light too which is why I think Urals cannot stay strong for much longer," said a refinery trader.
Even with Iraqi Kirkuk talking as high as 25 cents above the May Official Selling Price of Dated Brent -$2.20 a barrel basis fob Ceyhan, traders said it remained a much more attractive option.
"Kirkuk margins are better than Urals by about 50 cents," said a trader.
